comments.commentBody:
Most of the country likes such radical progressive measures as Social Security and Medicare. Congress has not surrendered to Obama, merely decided that a bloated government is better for the country than no government at all. The way to debloat the government is to debloat everywhere, including defense contract overruns and wasteful outsourcing of government activity, rather than playing chicken or flinch.

Most of the country is not Republican and does not want to be a very rich Mexico, where hard work usually does not get you very far if you are near the bottom.

This is unlikely to be true for anything other than out-of-print books that are scanned or even typed, in preparation for turning them into e-books. I have seen those, and yes, they are awful. But almost certainly what you're being told about are low-budget re-issues.

I design and set both print and e-books for a small publisher. When I'm making the e-book, I work with precisely the same file that was used to create the print book. Everybody does this. Yes, I then modify it in certain ways to make the e-book, but I don't edit and I don't re-type anything. If the print book has no errors, then the e-book will have no errors (excepting gross errors such as managing to lose an entire chapter or some pages). If the e-book has typos, then there were errors in the print book.

An e-book is nothing more than an HTML version of the files sent to the printer for printing and paper copy. An e-book is effectively a website, and as in so many things, the important relationship is "garbage in, garbage out."

I prefer eBooks for three reasons: (1) At any given time, I'm reading at least three books; so it's an eBook or a book bag. (2) I'm getting old and the print in books is harder for me to read (it may even by the the fonts in books are getting smaller to save on paper costs). I like being able to increase the size of the font. (3) I read books in Spanish as well as English, and like being able to just put my finger on a word I don't know to get the translation.

I don't like to read on the computer or tablet, but prefer a dedicated reader with e-Ink, because it's easier on the eye.

I, too, was amazed ( and appalled) by Mr. Walker's ignorance. He thought fighting teachers was comparable to fighting ISIS!!! He thought being an Eagle Scout qualified him to run the military??!! Such ignorance is rare even in a country known for its ignorance.
Thank God he is out of the race.
I couldn't agree more. I bought a Kindle early on. But, for many of the reasons that you cite, I have not used it for years now.

That's certainly true, if you narrowly look at the e-book costs. It's never taken me more than a day to make an e-book from the same files used to create a print book. Sometimes it's only a couple of hours (I make them for a small publisher). So for a publisher to talk about the great effort taken to make an e-book -- nonsense.

Even so, it's certainly true that the e-book piggybacks on the print book. You can't make an e-book without first having done all the work of creating a print book.

But it's also true that the distribution costs for the e-book approach zero, and there's also zero investment in warehouses full of them.

Where I live, getting to the nearest general-purpose "literary" bookstore requires air travel. And everything mildews. So although I love print books as much as anybody (and take great pleasure in creating them for the publisher), I'm almost exclusively on e-books now. That wouldn't be true if I lived in a big metropolitan area. But I don't.
Exactly! There is something about an electronic device while trying prepare to drift off to sleep which is very disconcerting.

If what he has already done to Wisconsinites wasn't enough to burnish his conservative chops, Heaven forefend what Walker will do now to buttress his credentials for his next run for national office.

We Minnesotans had better plan on taking in a lot of political refugees from Wisconsin.
The Green Bay Packers are 2 and 0. The team is better run than the Walker campaign was.

"He's very dynamic" says the Republican majority leader of the State Senate. For what, a stone?

He coasted to a dead stand still at 1/2 of 1%. Thank God he is gone. Even the Koch Bros could not package him for general consumption.
Time to roll up our sleeves, Wisconsin. We've got work to do to ensure this guy never gets elected to any office ever again.
The only one he qualifies under, is thrifty, to the detriment of everyone in his state, except his 1% friends.

He's obedient.

Just ask the Koch Bros. and the corporate fat cats who pull his strings.

It galled me to see Mr. Walker portray himself as an Eagle Scout then do the things he did. I may have been a Scout from an earlier time but the Scout Law is the same and still guides my life and what I do. A Scout is trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean and reverent. Mr. Walker is, from the start, not trustworthy.

I have mixed feelings about Walker coming back to plague Wisconsin again - dear God no!
But on the other hand, the idea of his anti-environment, anti-education, anti-teacher, anti-women's rights, anti-common-sense policies being in the White House was a truly frightening nightmare.
What a horrible little man, trying to, as he famously said "divide and conquer" us. He has no interest in bringing us together. But then again, neither do the Koch brothers or any of the Republican candidates - it's all about dividing us into groups and having each group hate the other group.
How anti-American and anti-Christian. So sad that we are even reading about this little creature.

Walker dropped out because his supporters wanted more anger, more color, more entertainment. Most of them likely migrated to Trump or Carson.

The same phenom will happen to the other far-right candidates, which means Cruz will fall next, and then in due course the less conservative candidates: Christie and eventually Bush. They're just not outrageous enough to hold on to voters who want fightin' words above all else.

The only GOP candidate who's safe from having his supporters poached by Trump, Carson and Fiorina is the Hispanic one.

Rubio will scoop up all the anti-Trump votes. Rubio will be the GOP nominee.

I never understand the durability argument for real books.  Water doesn't destroy them?  Really?  You must be using some fancy new fangled paper.  And it's pretty easy to keep sand and water out of a tablet...

This isn't surprising. E-books tire the eyes. Also, e-readers aren't as robust as print books (cold weather, water, sand, etc. destroy them, unlike paper books). Lastly, once you own a paper book you can lend it to anyone, resell, etc. No one is tracking your reading, selling that info to some other corporation, and so on. With e-books, who knows who's surveilling you (and some of the device makers and publishers have admitted they do so). Thanks, but, outside of occasional reading, presentations and free .pdfs, no thanks!

I think the Fed is acting in it's own interest. If it acts too soon it will squash the economic recovery and it doesn't want to get the blame for that.

The central bankers have consistently asked their govts for help in supporting economic demand with some form of fiscal support in whatever form is politically acceptable. Conservative politicians have consistently refused that fiscal support, saying let's be more competitive and make up the demand with exports. Increased exports haven't compensated for the withdrawal of govt spending. Now exports are looking weaker everywhere.

So the Fed knows that if it stuffs it up by increasing rates too soon in the face of weak demand and possible disinflation, the politicians are going to point the finger at them and say - your fault. There is not likely to be much help to keep the recovery on track with fiscal stimulus after that even if President Trump/Clinton/Sanders arrives because the Congress will still be in the hands of fiscal conservatives and the Europeans will still be as stubbornly hopeless as ever.
We don't want him either.
We were just hoping he would stay away for a while longer. Maybe Fox News will offer him a job.
Wow, coming from a guy in Texas that is saying a mouthful!

Nope, we're not thrilled to have him back.  And he in no way got any kind of a landslide victory.  Just about half the state didn't vote for him and are not at all happy about the GOP cabal in the statehouse (compliments of gerrymandering...). No one deserves this critter.
Wisconsin, I assume, is thrilled to have their man back.  Please do the rest of the USA a favor and keep him.  You wanted him and voted for him; he's all yours.  You deserve each other.
That's his claim to fame.

I can't imagine Scott Walker having a day-job at the helm of Wisconsin after showing such antagonisms while campaigning.  He compared dealing with the state legislature to doing battle in "Braveheart" and state unions to ISIS.  Trapped by his own inane, hyperbolic words.
But the motorcycle is built by union members.  I am sure he would try and change that.
Ironic, isn't it?  Harley Davidson, union made in Wisconsin.  One wonders about today's politics.
As they said about Nixon: would you buy a used car from this man? I pose the question:  would you buy a Harley from this man…he is clearly not qualified to be a salesman.
Maybe Scott Walker can try his hand as a Harley-Davidson salesman.  The only times he seemed happy as a candidate were talking about his love for that motorcycle.

I don't think Jeb! will bray because that's what Democratic donkeys do.

Republican elephants TRUMPet!
Without the talent.
I thought the late night comedians "dream team" would have been Walker and Palin.

Mr. Walker is a prime example of how an ill-educated preposterous pretender can worm their way up to the status of "Running for President". And we thought that distinction for relegated to the Vice Presidency.

Sarah Palin all again!

Scott Walker has been devastating for the state of Wisconsin, and I do not exaggerate when I say that it will probably take decades to recover. Imagine the havoc he could have wreaked as president.  The remaining problem is, of course, that any of the other GOP candidates has the potential to be equally destructive, if elected.

We can help a lot of these people get back their footing and live good and productive lives.  It will take a lot of effort, but it can be done.  I think a place to start my be to retrofit abandoned properties to make them into treatment facilities where public and private monies could be funneled in to fund operations.  There are so many good decent people out there who just need another chance to make things go right.  Some are pretty far gone into substance abuse and mental illness, but they too should not be forgotten.

What? Is that why acceptance rates at Harvard are now 6%, because the "gifted children" are forgotten? No it's because the competition is  much stiffer - precisely because there is so much investment in elite eduction. The top echelon is doing terrific academically and we invest heavily in them.

Why not 100 million for the most neglected population, our genius youths that will lead this country out of this poverty we have created. The neglected population are gifted children forgotten by the ever rising popularity of victimhood.
